an6.11:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these six warm-hearted qualities.
an6.11:4.3: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private. This is a warm-hearted quality.
an6.11:5.1: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private. This is a warm-hearted quality.
an6.11:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
an6.11:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions. This is a warm-hearted quality.
an6.11:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are uncorrupted, unflawed, unblemished, untainted, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to samādhi. This is a warm-hearted quality.
an6.11:9.1: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete end of suffering. This is a warm-hearted quality.
an6.11:10.1: These are the six warm-hearted qualities.”
